text: hi my name is peg and I'm one of the
clinical dietitians at Roswell Park
today we're going to talk about an
introduction to carbohydrate counting
for people with diabetes the first thing
you need to do in order to count your
carbohydrates is to determine your
caloric goal first you find your weight
in kilograms by dividing your weight in
pounds by 2.2 for example if you weigh a
hundred and fifty-two pounds you divide
that by 2.2 you come up with 69
kilograms then you take a quick
calculation by the number of kilograms
times 29 and that's a multiplier used to
determine your maintenance calories your
carbohydrate goal for the day is
approximately forty to sixty percent of
your total calories carbohydrates
support activity they give you energy so
I want you to think of your carbohydrate
base as your fuel for the day now where
do carbohydrates come from well they're
in starches breads pastas rice potatoes
corn simple sugars and desserts I have
cut potato or 1/3 cup of pasta or rice
or a tablespoon of sugar honey or maple
syrup are all examples of one
carbohydrate choice so this is a sweet
potato this is about a cup this would be
two carbohydrate servings this pasta is
actually a half cup of cooked pasta so
it's slightly more than one serving of
pasta and this baked potato is
approximately 1/2 cup of potato if you
don't eat the skin so this would be one
serving of baked potato now a cup of
milk or a serving of yogurt without
added sugar is also a carbohydrate
serving we have some yogurt here and
this is just a plain yogurt and on the
back the label says carbohydrate 12
grams so this is a no added sugar choice
of yogurt which is a great choice and
then this yogurt is called fruit side
and this one has told total
carbohydrates 26 grams
and the added sugars are 12 grams so
this is almost two servings of
carbohydrate so you see the difference
carbohydrates are also in fruits a
medium orange a medium apple a cup of
berries four ounces juice or a half cup
of canned pears in their own juice are
examples of one serving of fruit now I
only have one fruit sample here and this
is cantaloupe and this is approximately
a cup so one cup of melon is also one
fruit serving every 15 grams of
carbohydrate equals one carbohydrate
choice so when you read a label every 15
grams of carbohydrate is one choice so I
said that twice so you can remember that
so when we looked at this yogurt the
label says 12 grams of carbohydrate so
that's approximately one serving of
carbohydrate and in the one with the
added sugar
the total carbohydrate is 26 grams so
again that is two carbohydrate servings
whether there are added sugars or not
your total carbohydrate is what matters
in your body all carbohydrates break
down into sugar some enter the
bloodstream faster than others these are
called high glycemic carbohydrates some
choices are donuts or pastries a low
glycemic carbohydrate and ters the
bloodstream slowly plain yogurt is an
example of a low glycemic carbohydrate
so counting carbs and staying within
your carbohydrate range for the day is a
vital goal in achieving glucose control
here's a choice of a 2,000 calorie
eating plan with four carbohydrate
choices per meal and three carbohydrate
choices for a snack so if you look at
some of these meals like for example the
breakfast has two slices of toast where
one slice of toast is a carbohydrate
choice four ounces of juice is a choice
and the six ounces of low-fat yogurt is
a choice and you should always consult
your dietitian and ask for a referral or
a consult and we can help you out a
little bit further but this can give you
an introductory method to how do you
start to count carbs
you
